name: The World's Best Vegan Melted Cheese
description: This vegan cheese tastes like cheese and has a strong cheese aftertaste. The glutinous flour creates the firm and slightly chewy texture of melted cheese. The flax seeds creates its slimy quality. The cheese will always stay melted and will not harden. The top of the cheese can dry and solidify if toasted. It can be used for macaroni and cheese, fondue, toasts, pasta sauce, lasagna, burgers, sandwiches, cheese fries. You can put the mixture in a piping bag and squeeze it over the top of pizza to form random streaks of cheese over the toppings.
recipeIngredient: 1 ½ cups water, or more as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Mix water, chickpea flour, rice flour, nutritional yeast, and flax seeds in a saucepan until dissolved. Add oil, onion, and garlic.
Place saucepan over low heat; cook and stir until mixture is the consistency of melted cheese, about 10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper.

aggregateRating.itemReviewed: The World's Best Vegan Melted Cheese

review.reviewBody: This may vey well be the World's best vegan cheese. It is delicious and took minutes to make.  I added a bit extra nutritional yeast because my chickpea flour gave it a slight bitter taste. The extra yeast toned that down. I served it with tortillas for a vegan version of chips and queso. Thank you for the recipe.

I like this recipe and my son likes it on broccoli. I needed much more water than the recipe calls for. I used two cups initially and two more during the simmering. I doubled the amount of nutritional yeast and added a teaspoon each of turmeric and smoked paprika to give it a stronger cheese flavor and color. Keep stirring to prevent lumps!

I make vegan cheese sauce all the time and was really looking forward to trying this one. Other than doubling it and adding a dash of turmeric and smoked paprika for color, I followed the recipe exactly. I don't know what happened, but it just tasted awful - flour-y and flavorless to the point of being bitter.

When I made it I didnt have chickpea flour so I ended up using 1/4 cup more of the rice flour and a 1/4 cup of all purpose flour. It ended up just looking and tasting like gravy. I made a bunch of changes to it and ended up making it edible. Added almond milk lemon juice some cayenne powder garlic powder extra nutritional yeast and then even melted store bought vegan cheese into it. Tastes somewhat like cheese now but also tastes like an almond dip.

I make something very similar to this. Only differences, are that I use all rice flour, to avoid bitterness of chickpeas. I specifically use sunflower oil, and I add taco seasoning mix to make it taste like taco cheese. Make sure your keeping your pan on low or slightly higher heat, and get a highly fine ground flour, pastry flour is great for things like this as well. Please don't diss the recipe, it could be a coarse flour you used. You may try blending the flour first in a magic bullet or similar before adding to the pan. Great recipe!!
